elements.content: Two lithium-based coordination polymers and a framework Li3(C7H3O4N)2·0.21(H2O) (C2H8N) [1]; ULCP-1 (ULCP = ultralight coordination polymer); Li3(C7H3O4N)·(C6H3O2N) [2]; [ULCP-1A]; and Li2(C7H3O4N) [3]; ULMOF-4 (ULMOF = ultralight metal organic framework) were synthesized using solvothermal techniques. The compounds were characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods and thermal analysis techniques. Compound [1] [space group P21/c, a = 11.51(2) Å, b = 15.33(3) Å, c = 10.93(2) Å, β = 99.98(3)°] consists of trimeric corner- and edge-sharing lithium tetrahedral chains. Organic linkers connect each of these chains to form a two-dimensional (2-D) layered structure. Positively charged dimethyl amine (DMA) molecules and sites partially occupied by water molecules are present between the layers. Compound [2] [space group P21/c, a = 10.190(2) Å, b = 13.390(3) Å, c = 10.450(2) Å, β = 106.02(3)°] contains trimeric clusters of corner- and edge-sharing lithium tetrahedra. Each of these clusters is connected by the organic linkers to form an overall 2-D structure. Compound [3] [space group C2/c, a = 12.692(2) Å, b = 10.977(2) Å, c = 11.200(2) Å, β = 105.83(3)°] consists of edge- and corner shared one-dimensional (1-D) chains of lithium tetrahedra. The lithium polyhedral chains are then connected by the organic linkers to form a dense three-dimensional (3-D) network. All compounds are stable above 300 °C under N2 atmosphere, with [3] stable to 550 °C.

elements.content: Two ultralight metal (Li) based coordination polymers (ULCP) and one framework (ULMOF) were synthesized using solvothermal techniques and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermal methods. 2,6-Pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,6-PDC, C7H5O4N) and 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (3,5-PDC, C7H5O4N) were used as organic linkers. Networks of different dimensionalities (2-D polymer and 3-D framework) are generated depending on the position of the carboxylate groups with respect to pyridyl nitrogen. All the compounds are stable to temperatures above 300 °C under N2 atmosphere.
elements.clean_text: Two ultralight metal (Li) based coordination polymers (ULCP) and one framework (ULMOF) were synthesized using solvothermal techniques and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermal methods. 2,6-Pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,6-PDC, C7H5O4N) and 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (3,5-PDC, C7H5O4N) were used as organic linkers. Networks of different dimensionalities (2-D polymer and 3-D framework) are generated depending on the position of the carboxylate groups with respect to pyridyl nitrogen. All the compounds are stable to temperatures above 300 °C under N2 atmosphere.

elements.content: A wide range of metal-centers forms coordination polymers (CPs) and frameworks (MOFs) through linkages with multifunctional organic ligands. First row transition metals are popular choices as the coordination centers for the design and discovery of these materials due to their well-known coordination behavior with polycarboxylates and their tendency to form secondary building units (e.g., the paddle wheel unit for copper(II) center). These properties are used to design three-dimensional (3-D) networks potentially useful in gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, and separation. More recently, dense frameworks have been explored for possible functionality in fields such as magnetism and metallic conductance. Further, the gravimetric advantages of using lightweight coordinating centers (Li, B, Mg) for the design of MOFs have also recently been recognized. Frameworks constructed with lithium are of particular interest since studies indicate strong electrostatic interactions between adsorbed H2 and the lithium centers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A wide range of metal-centers forms coordination polymers (CPs) and frameworks (MOFs) through linkages with multifunctional organic ligands. First row transition metals are popular choices as the coordination centers for the design and discovery of these materials due to their well-known coordination behavior with polycarboxylates and their tendency to form secondary building units (e.g., the paddle wheel unit for copper(II) center). These properties are used to design three-dimensional (3-D) networks potentially useful in gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, and separation. More recently, dense frameworks have been explored for possible functionality in fields such as magnetism and metallic conductance. Further, the gravimetric advantages of using lightweight coordinating centers (Li, B, Mg) for the design of MOFs have also recently been recognized. Frameworks constructed with lithium are of particular interest since studies indicate strong electrostatic interactions between adsorbed H2 and the lithium centers.

elements.content: The nature of the organic linkers also controls the topology and properties of the networks. Different structural isomers of pyridine dicarboxylic acids (2,6-, 2,5-, 3,5-, and 2,4-PDC) are of contemporary interest as linkers due to the presence of both nitrogen and oxygen based functional group along with a rigid aromatic backbone. These linkers have been used to form first row transition metal and lanthanide based coordination networks of varying topologies.

These linkers have been used to form first row transition metal and lanthanide based coordination networks of varying topologies.

elements.content: We were motivated to explore the type of networks that form by combining the potential of strong interaction with adsorbed gases in the case of lithium based networks, with the structural diversity present in the pyridine dicarboxylate system. Here, we describe solvothermal synthesis and structural characterization of three compounds forming either 2-D coordination polymers (ULCP) [Li3(2,6-PDC)2·0.21(H2O)(DMA) (ULCP-1), Li3(2,6-PDC)·(2-PC) (ULCP-1A), or a 3-D network (ULMOF) [Li2(3,5-PDC) (ULMOF-4)] as part of our ongoing study on ultralight metal (Li) based metal organic coordination polymers and frameworks.

elements.content: All compounds were synthesized under solvothermalconditions using Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr autoclaves. Starting materials include lithium nitrate (LiNO3, 99+%, Acros-Organic), lithium hydroxide (LiOH·H2O, 98%, Alfa-Aesar), 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylic acid (2,6-PDC, 99%, Acros-Organic), 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (3,5-PDC, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), and ethanol (99%, Sigma-Aldrich) and were used without any further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

All compounds were synthesized under solvothermalconditions using Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr autoclaves. Starting materials include lithium nitrate (LiNO3, 99+%, Acros-Organic), lithium hydroxide (LiOH⋅H2O, 98%, Alfa-Aesar), 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylic acid (2,6-PDC, 99%, Acros-Organic), 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (3,5-PDC, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), and ethanol (99%, Sigma-Aldrich) and were used without any further purification.

elements.content: A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,6-PDC (0.85 g), 0.0025 mol of LiNO3 (0.175 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH·H2O (0.0214 g) was dissolved in 15 g of DMF and stirred for 4 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal nitrate/ligand/solvent = 1:2:82]. The resultant solution was heated at 100 °C for 5 days. Colorless plate-shaped crystals were recovered as products and washed with DMF and ethanol (yield: 55% based on Li).
elements.clean_text:
Compound [1]: Li3(C7H3NO4)2⋅0.21(H2O)(C2H8N), ULCP-1

A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,6-PDC (0.85 g), 0.0025 mol of LiNO3 (0.175 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH⋅H2O (0.0214 g) was dissolved in 15 g of DMF and stirred for 4 h to achieve homogeneity [molar ratio of metal nitrate/ligand/solvent = 1:2:82]. The resultant solution was heated at 100 °C for 5 days. Colorless plate-shaped crystals were recovered as products and washed with DMF and ethanol (yield: 55% based on Li).

elements.content: A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,6-PDC (0.85 g), 0.0025 mol of LiNO3 (0.175 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH·H2O (0.021gram) were dissolved in 14 g of DMF. The resultant solution was stirred for 3 h to achieve homogeneity and subsequently heated at 180 °C for 5 days [molar ratio of metal nitrate/ligand/solvent = 1:2:76]. The product was obtained as needle-shaped crystals and washed with DMF and ethanol (yield: 45% based on lithium).
elements.clean_text:
Compound [2]: Li3(C7H3O4N)⋅(C6H3O2N), ULCP-1A

A mixture of 0.005 mol of 2,6-PDC (0.85 g), 0.0025 mol of LiNO3 (0.175 g), and 0.0005 mol of LiOH⋅H2O (0.021gram) were dissolved in 14 g of DMF. The resultant solution was stirred for 3 h to achieve homogeneity and subsequently heated at 180 °C for 5 days [molar ratio of metal nitrate/ligand/solvent = 1:2:76]. The product was obtained as needle-shaped crystals and washed with DMF and ethanol (yield: 45% based on lithium).

elements.content: A mixture of 0.0025 mol of 3,5-PDC (0.425 g), 0.0025 mol of LiNO3 (0.174 g), and 0.001 mol of LiOH (0.042 g) were dissolved in 8 g of DMF. The resulting solution was stirred for 1 h (molar ratio of metal nitrate/ligand/solvent = 1:1:43) to ensure the homogeneity of the solution and then was heated for 5 days at 180 °C. Colorless needle-shaped crystals were recovered by filtration and subsequent washing by DMF (yield: 50% based on Li).
elements.clean_text:
Compound [3]: Li2(C7H3O4N), ULMOF-4 

A mixture of 0.0025 mol of 3,5-PDC (0.425 g), 0.0025 mol of LiNO3 (0.174 g), and 0.001 mol of LiOH (0.042 g) were dissolved in 8 g of DMF. The resulting solution was stirred for 1 h (molar ratio of metal nitrate/ligand/solvent = 1:1:43) to ensure the homogeneity of the solution and then was heated for 5 days at 180 °C. Colorless needle-shaped crystals were recovered by filtration and subsequent washing by DMF (yield: 50% based on Li).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of each compound were selected from the bulk sample and were mounted on a glass fiber using epoxy. Reflections for the compounds were collected using a Bruker four circle P4 single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with software packages SMART and SAINT. An empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS and the crystal structures were solved using direct methods (SHELXS). Oxygen atoms were located first, followed by the determination of other atoms positions (C, N, Li) from the Fourier difference map with all of the non-hydrogen atoms being refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were added to the pyridine rings using geometrical constraints. The crystallographic details can be found in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of each compound were selected from the bulk sample and were mounted on a glass fiber using epoxy. Reflections for the compounds were collected using a Bruker four circle P4 single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with software packages SMART and SAINT. An empirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS and the crystal structures were solved using direct methods (SHELXS). Oxygen atoms were located first, followed by the determination of other atoms positions (C, N, Li) from the Fourier difference map with all of the non-hydrogen atoms being refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were added to the pyridine rings using geometrical constraints. The crystallographic details can be found in Table .

Contained within the structure of [1] is a site partially occupied solvent water molecule. After the positions of atoms comprising the layer and dimethylamine (DMA) solvent had been assigned, a large residual electron density peak remained. This peak was assigned as a site for a solvent water molecule and its occupation factor was refined to a value of 20.5(6)%.

elements.content: Bulk sample identification and phase purity were determined using powder X-ray diffraction. The data were collected using a Scintag Pad-X diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation within a range of 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 40° (step size: 0.02°, counting time: 1 s/step). The powder patterns collected were consistent with the simulated patterns based on the single crystal data (). In situ high temperature X-ray powder diffraction of compound [1] was conducted on a Bruker AXS diffractometer equipped with an electronic multiwire area detector system, in order to observe the changes in the X-ray diffraction pattern during the thermal decomposition of the sample. A powder sample was obtained by grinding, and this was loaded in a Kapton capillary for heating by an air blower heater. The temperature was maintained at 330 °C during the data collection (Figure ).

elements.content: Combined TGA-DSC data analysis was performed using a Netzsch 449C Jupiter instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 750 °C under a flowing N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min (Figures −).

elements.content: ULCP-1 forms a negatively charged layered structure with charge compensating protonated DMA and solvent water molecules occupying sites between the layers (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of ULCP-1 shown in Figure contains two 2,6-PDC linkers connected to three crystallographically unique lithium centers. Each lithium center is present in a distorted tetrahedral coordination. Li1 is connected to four carboxylate oxygens from four different organic linkers. Li2 and Li3 are each connected to three carboxylate oxygens and one pyridyl nitrogen from three different organic linkers. One organic linker acts as a bidentate chelating ligand (O6−Li2−N2) among the contributing ligands. The Li−O bond lengths of Li2 and Li3 vary between 1.917(4) and 2.189(6) Å (Table ). For Li1, the Li−O bond lengths vary between 1.880(4) and 1.993(4) Å (Table ). The bond valence calculation showed that the bond valence sum of the lithium centers, 1.08 v.u. (Li1), 0.94 (Li2), and 0.95 (Li3), are close to the expected value of +1 (v.u. = valence unit).

Structural Description of [1], Li3(2,6-PDC)2⋅0.21(H2O)(DMA), ULCP-1 

ULCP-1 forms a negatively charged layered structure with charge compensating protonated DMA and solvent water molecules occupying sites between the layers (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of ULCP-1 shown in Figure  contains two 2,6-PDC linkers connected to three crystallographically unique lithium centers. Each lithium center is present in a distorted tetrahedral coordination. Li1 is connected to four carboxylate oxygens from four different organic linkers. Li2 and Li3 are each connected to three carboxylate oxygens and one pyridyl nitrogen from three different organic linkers. One organic linker acts as a bidentate chelating ligand (O6-Li2-N2) among the contributing ligands. The Li-O bond lengths of Li2 and Li3 vary between 1.917(4) and 2.189(6) Å (Table ). For Li1, the Li-O bond lengths vary between 1.880(4) and 1.993(4) Å (Table ). The bond valence calculation showed that the bond valence sum of the lithium centers, 1.08 v.u. (Li1), 0.94 (Li2), and 0.95 (Li3), are close to the expected value of +1 (v.u. = valence unit).

The strength of the bonding interactions between the carboxylate oxygens with the metal centers appears to depend on the position of the oxygen with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen in the aromatic ring. The carboxylate oxygen atoms (O3, O4, O5, and O6) geometrically positioned toward the pyridyl nitrogen show a very weak interaction with the metal centers (Table ). One oxygen center is not coordinated with any metal centers; rather, it interacts with the amine present within the layers. The average Li−N bond distance is found to be 2.08 Å in ULCP-1.

elements.content: The lithium tetrahedra are form trimers by edge- and corner-sharing. The trimers are further connected by 2,6-PDC to form layers, which pack in such a way that channels large enough to accommodate the DMA and water molecules are formed. These molecules (DMA and water) are involved in strong H-bonding with the carboxylate oxygen of the organic linkers (Table ). The position of the DMA molecules can be seen as a result of the H-bonding with the protonated nitrogen interacting with the carboxylate oxygens from the layer. The water molecules are present between two DMA molecules along the [001] direction with an average distance of 3.5 Å from each DMA molecule. The small size of the channel, the zigzag type 2-D layer, and strong H-bonding make it unlikely for DMA and water molecules to move freely along the [001] direction in the channel.

ULCP-1A consists of trimeric clusters of tetrahedral lithium metal centers connected by 2,6-PDC and 2-PC to form a layered structure (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of ULCP-1A includes two organic linker molecules (2,6-PDC, 2-PC) and three crystallographically unique lithium centers (Figure ). Although each Li atom is found in a distorted tetrahedral coordination, there are differences between the coordination environments of the three Li centers arising from the type of ligand and bonding involved. Li1 is connected to four separate organic linkers (three 2,6-PDC and one 2-PC) through four carboxylate oxygen atoms. Li2 and Li3 are each connected to three organic linkers by coordination with three carboxylate oxygens and one pyridyl nitrogen. 2,6-PDC and 2-PC act as bidentate chelating agents in the case of Li2 and Li3, respectively. The average Li−O bond length is found to be 1.971 Å, while the pyridyl nitrogens (N1, N2) are found to reside at an average distance of 2.09 Å from their respective lithium metal centers (Table ). The bond valence calculation showed that the bond valence sum of the lithium centers are 1.07 v.u. (Li1) and 1.02 (Li2, Li3), which are close to the expected value of +1.

The major structural feature of ULCP-1A is the in situ formation of 2-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2-PC) by the partial decarboxylation of 2,6-PDC molecule. The formation of 2-PC gives rise to significant structural difference between ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A. ULCP-1A forms a neutral layered structure due to the presence of 2-PC as the constituent of the layer. The basic building unit of each layer is the trimeric corner- and edge-shared lithium tetrahedral clusters (). Li1 and Li3 form edge-shared dimers that are connected by Li2 tetrahedra by corner-sharing to form the trimeric basic building unit. The distance between two Li centers in the dimer is 2.579(4) Å. The average distance between the corner-shared lithium centers is found to be 3.35 Å. The building units are connected to each other by both organic linkers forming the 2-D layer. The direction of connectivity depends on the type of linker; for example, 2,6-PDC connects the building unit in both [010] and [001] directions, while 2-PC connects along the [001] direction only. The 2-D layers are arranged in an ordered fashion such that the hydrophobic aromatic rings from successive layers point toward each other. The average distance between each layer is 1.8 Å. indicating strong van der Waals interaction between each layers.

The average distance between each layer is 1.8 Å. indicating strong van der Waals interaction between each layers.

elements.content: ULMOF-4 consists of a one-dimensional (1-D) chain of edge- and corner-shared lithium polyhedra connected by organic linkers to form a 3-D network (Figure ). The asymmetric unit (Figure ) of ULMOF-4 comprises of the organic linker (3,5-PDC) and two crystallographically unique lithium metal centers (Li1 and Li2). Each lithium metal center is present in distorted tetrahedral coordination as observed before in the case of ULCP-1 and 1A. The average bond length of Li1, tetrahedrally connected to four carboxylate oxygens (O2, O3, and O4) is found to be 1.977 Å. In the case of Li2, it is coordinated to three carboxylate oxygens and one pyridyl nitrogen with an average Li−O distance of 1.93 Å (Table ). Each of the lithium metal centers is coordinated to four different organic linkers through their respective coordinating atoms (carboxylate oxygens or pyridyl nitrogens). One of the major differences between ULMOF-4 and the two preceding structures (ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A) is the absence of chelating mode of the organic linkers in ULMOF-4. All the carboxylate oxygens are connected to two lithium centers except O2, which is connected to only Li1. The bond valence sum of two lithium centers (Li1 and Li2) are 1.01 and 1.10 v.u., respectively, which matches well with the expected value of +1.

The main structural feature of ULMOF-4 is the presence of infinite 1-D edge- and corner- shared lithium polyhedra chain. It is distinct from the isolated trimeric lithium polyhedra clusters observed in ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A. Each type of lithium center (Li1 and Li2, respectively) forms a dimer by edge-sharing. These edge-shared dimers are then connected to each other by corner-sharing to form an infinite 1-D chain with the average distance between the lithium centers in the dimer being 2.72 Å. The chains are then connected to each other by the organic linkers forming the overall 3-D network. Each 3,5-PDC molecule connects with three 1-D chains. The distance between each chain is on average 4.97 Å along the [100] direction.

elements.content: The approach to design multidimensional coordination polymers is influenced by the coordination geometry of the metal center and the form and functionality of organic linkers. As an example, in the presence of carboxylate groups lithium centers commonly form distorted tetrahedra, which causes the position of the functional groups on the organic linker to play a pivotal role in determining the overall topology. Two structural isomers of pyridinedicarboxylic acid were used in the current study. The isomers have different carboxylic acid group positions with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen, but the mutual angle between them is the same (120°). Lithium, a hard acid center, is expected to interact with the carboxylate oxygen rather than softer pyridyl nitrogen. However, the position of pyridyl nitrogen appears to be the driving force behind the formation of the structures. Two different types of lithium centers are present in the structures based on the nature of the coordinating atoms of the ligands. One type of lithium center is coordinated with four oxygens, while the other type is coordinated with three carboxylate oxygens and one pyridyl nitrogen. Lithium metal centers are present in distorted tetrahedral coordination in both cases. The bonding contributions of Li−N bonds are similar to that of Li−O bonds based on calculation of bond-valence. The presence of pyridyl nitrogen between two carboxylate groups enhances the chelating ability of the ligand (2,6-PDC) to the metal center constraining the possible coordination modes of the ligand. The effort to increase the dimensionality by (a) increasing the OH− content of the solution (i.e., the addition of more LiOH) or (b) increasing the reaction temperature to 180 °C under similar solvothermal conditions failed to give a higher dimensional structure. The higher temperature reaction under similar molar ratios of the reactants yields a two-dimensional (2-D) polymeric layered structure (ULCP-1A). The chelating ability of 2,6-PDC thus proved to be the decisive factor in the formation of both layered structures (ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A).
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The approach to design multidimensional coordination polymers is influenced by the coordination geometry of the metal center and the form and functionality of organic linkers. As an example, in the presence of carboxylate groups lithium centers commonly form distorted tetrahedra, which causes the position of the functional groups on the organic linker to play a pivotal role in determining the overall topology. Two structural isomers of pyridinedicarboxylic acid were used in the current study. The isomers have different carboxylic acid group positions with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen, but the mutual angle between them is the same (120°). Lithium, a hard acid center, is expected to interact with the carboxylate oxygen rather than softer pyridyl nitrogen. However, the position of pyridyl nitrogen appears to be the driving force behind the formation of the structures. Two different types of lithium centers are present in the structures based on the nature of the coordinating atoms of the ligands. One type of lithium center is coordinated with four oxygens, while the other type is coordinated with three carboxylate oxygens and one pyridyl nitrogen. Lithium metal centers are present in distorted tetrahedral coordination in both cases. The bonding contributions of Li-N bonds are similar to that of Li-O bonds based on calculation of bond-valence. The presence of pyridyl nitrogen between two carboxylate groups enhances the chelating ability of the ligand (2,6-PDC) to the metal center constraining the possible coordination modes of the ligand. The effort to increase the dimensionality by (a) increasing the OH- content of the solution (i.e., the addition of more LiOH) or (b) increasing the reaction temperature to 180 °C under similar solvothermal conditions failed to give a higher dimensional structure. The higher temperature reaction under similar molar ratios of the reactants yields a two-dimensional (2-D) polymeric layered structure (ULCP-1A). The chelating ability of 2,6-PDC thus proved to be the decisive factor in the formation of both layered structures (ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A).

elements.content: The interaction between lithium metal centers and 3,5-PDC on the other hand generates a 3D structure under similar solvothermal conditions at 180 °C. The effort to synthesize a material using a similar reactant ratio at 100 °C resulted in a clear solution. The position of the two carboxylate groups with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen group in 3,5-PDC prevents it from acting as a chelating agent, unlike 2,6-PDC. The higher degree of freedom for possible coordination mode results in a 3-D metal organic framework (ULMOF-4).

The effort to synthesize a material using a similar reactant ratio at 100 °C resulted in a clear solution. The position of the two carboxylate groups with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen group in 3,5-PDC prevents it from acting as a chelating agent, unlike 2,6-PDC. The higher degree of freedom for possible coordination mode results in a 3-D metal organic framework (ULMOF-4).

elements.content: All three networks are thermally stable over 300 °C under N2 atmosphere (Figures −). ULCP-1 follows a two-step decomposition pathway (Figure ). The first weight loss is attributed to the loss of the solvent water and DMA molecules and decarboxylation of one of the carboxylate groups (calculated: 23.35%, observed 23.1%) followed by collapse of the structure at 450 °C. ULCP-1A shows similar thermal stability and decomposes at 425 °C in a single step due to the absence of any solvent molecules within the layer (Figure ). The stability of ULMOF-4 is much higher (550 °C) than ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A as expected due to the 3D nature of the framework (Figure ).

ULCP-1A shows similar thermal stability and decomposes at 425 °C in a single step due to the absence of any solvent molecules within the layer (Figure ). The stability of ULMOF-4 is much higher (550 °C) than ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A as expected due to the 3D nature of the framework (Figure ).

elements.content: The decarboxylation and solvent removal upon heating of ULCP-1 under nitrogen atmosphere motivates us to investigate the mechanism using the in situ PXRD technique at 330 °C (Figure ). The time-dependent in situ PXRD study showed that a new phase is generated upon heating over time. This new phase is formed through an intermediate transitional amorphous phase and is an irreversible transition. Because of its poor crystallinity, we were unable to characterize the final phase using single crystal XRD. The addition of DMF or DMA did not regenerate the initial compound ULCP-1. The irreversibility of this process is expected, as the removal of the solvent molecules and the partial decarboxylation of the ligand would destroy the interaction between the layers.
elements.clean_text: The decarboxylation and solvent removal upon heating of ULCP-1 under nitrogen atmosphere motivates us to investigate the mechanism using the in situ PXRD technique at 330 °C (Figure ). The time-dependent in situ PXRD study showed that a new phase is generated upon heating over time. This new phase is formed through an intermediate transitional amorphous phase and is an irreversible transition. Because of its poor crystallinity, we were unable to characterize the final phase using single crystal XRD. The addition of DMF or DMA did not regenerate the initial compound ULCP-1. The irreversibility of this process is expected, as the removal of the solvent molecules and the partial decarboxylation of the ligand would destroy the interaction between the layers.

elements.content: Two new coordination polymers and one metal organic framework have been synthesized using lithium as the metal center and two structural isomers of pyridinedicarboxylic acid. The networks contain both edge- and corner-shared lithium tetrahedra connected by organic linkers to form thermally stable networks. The resulting topologies differ from each other based on the position of the functional carboxylate groups with reference to the pyridine group in the ring. The detailed structural characterization and thermal study enable us to understand the chemistry of this underexplored and potentially interesting class of materials. We continue to search for novel topologies and properties that might be available by combining ultralight metals with a variety of ligands and synthetic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two new coordination polymers and one metal organic framework have been synthesized using lithium as the metal center and two structural isomers of pyridinedicarboxylic acid. The networks contain both edge- and corner-shared lithium tetrahedra connected by organic linkers to form thermally stable networks. The resulting topologies differ from each other based on the position of the functional carboxylate groups with reference to the pyridine group in the ring. The detailed structural characterization and thermal study enable us to understand the chemistry of this underexplored and potentially interesting class of materials. We continue to search for novel topologies and properties that might be available by combining ultralight metals with a variety of ligands and synthetic conditions.

cln_elements.content:
Two lithium-based coordination polymers and a framework Li3(C7H3O4N)2·0.21(H2O) (C2H8N) [1]; ULCP-1 (ULCP = ultralight coordination polymer); Li3(C7H3O4N)·(C6H3O2N) [2]; [ULCP-1A]; and Li2(C7H3O4N) [3]; ULMOF-4 (ULMOF = ultralight metal organic framework) were synthesized using solvothermal techniques. The compounds were characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods and thermal analysis techniques. Compound [1] [space group P21/c, a = 11.51(2) Å, b = 15.33(3) Å, c = 10.93(2) Å, β = 99.98(3)°] consists of trimeric corner- and edge-sharing lithium tetrahedral chains. Organic linkers connect each of these chains to form a two-dimensional (2-D) layered structure. Positively charged dimethyl amine (DMA) molecules and sites partially occupied by water molecules are present between the layers. Compound [2] [space group P21/c, a = 10.190(2) Å, b = 13.390(3) Å, c = 10.450(2) Å, β = 106.02(3)°] contains trimeric clusters of corner- and edge-sharing lithium tetrahedra. Each of these clusters is connected by the organic linkers to form an overall 2-D structure. Compound [3] [space group C2/c, a = 12.692(2) Å, b = 10.977(2) Å, c = 11.200(2) Å, β = 105.83(3)°] consists of edge- and corner shared one-dimensional (1-D) chains of lithium tetrahedra. The lithium polyhedral chains are then connected by the organic linkers to form a dense three-dimensional (3-D) network. All compounds are stable above 300 °C under N2 atmosphere, with [3] stable to 550 °C.

All three networks are thermally stable over 300 °C under N2 atmosphere (Figures −). ULCP-1 follows a two-step decomposition pathway (Figure ). The first weight loss is attributed to the loss of the solvent water and DMA molecules and decarboxylation of one of the carboxylate groups (calculated: 23.35%, observed 23.1%) followed by collapse of the structure at 450 °C. ULCP-1A shows similar thermal stability and decomposes at 425 °C in a single step due to the absence of any solvent molecules within the layer (Figure ). The stability of ULMOF-4 is much higher (550 °C) than ULCP-1 and ULCP-1A as expected due to the 3D nature of the framework (Figure ).
